Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM0999 - myBCom Blueprint","description":"

The course will provide students with the core skills necessary to prepare for their career based on a self-reflection of values, abilities, interests and emerging career aspirations. Through an exploration of both curricular and co-curricular opportunities from the Business School, students will be able to critically evaluate and plan for a range of professional pathways. The resulting personalised action plan will assist every student to be career capable and equipped for change and adaptation.

contentlets.description: The course will provide students with the core skills necessary to prepare for their career based on a self-reflection of values, abilities, interests and emerging career aspirations. Through an exploration of both curricular and co-curricular opportunities from the Business School, students will be able to critically evaluate and plan for a range of professional pathways. The resulting personalised action plan will assist every student to be career capable and equipped for change and adaptation.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM1000 - Creating Social Change: From Innovation to Impact","description":"

Do you want to lead change and implement social innovations? Would you like to find ways to address complex social problems? This course is for aspiring change agents across all sectors, including business, not-for-profit and government. Whether your career lies in business, law, art and design, arts and social sciences, the built environment, science, engineering or medicine, you will develop practical skills to lead complex systems for create better social outcomes. We explore the issues that policy makers, industry leaders and social service providers grapple with every day, such as inequality, place-based disadvantage, mental health, homelessness, and human rights. We will introduce models for systems change, social innovation, and cross-sectoral collaboration. You will complete the course with a broad understanding of social systems and the keys to initiating and sustaining positive social change. The course introduces local and global trends through a range of case studies, and you will have the opportunity to hear directly from experts in business, government and social purpose organisations who have successfully initiated social change.

This is an oral presentation of your section of the change process. In this presentation, you ‘pitch’ your individual section of the team report. It will be delivered in class/on line with your team members, and you will present your individual section of the change process.

The presentation must be 5 minutes long.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"53e065f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"9fe065f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"dbe065f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"07e025f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Multiple Choice Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

You are required to complete two multiple choice quizzes each of 20 questions and each worth 20% of your final mark (40% in total). The first quiz is on the core concepts introduced in weeks 1, 2, and 3 of the course, and the second quiz is on the core concepts introduced in weeks 4, 5 and 6 of the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0be065f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"57e065f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cbe065f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961907","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b2e025f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Social Change Pitch (a)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

The Social Change Pitch has three assessment tasks: 2(a) Individual written report (25%); 2(b) Individual oral presentation (25%); and 2(c) Team design and presentation (10%).

To complete the entire task you will be allocated to a team of three (3) or four (4). In your team you will choose a social issue based on the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). During the course your team will design a change process to address this social issue, and will present a social change pitch in the form of a written report and an oral presentation.

For your social change pitch, you are asked to focus on designing a Process rather than a solution. To design your change process you will need to use the tools discussed in the course. This part is where you get to apply what you have learnt. Remember that you need to design your overall change process justifying your approach to change as well as your choice of specific tools to go about this change drawing on the material covered during the course.

This section should be very practical rather than written in an essay style. Your report should be structured as a report and in a professional manner. It is recommended that you do some research as to what a professional report looks like.

Your team’s social change pitch is divided in 4 sections:

(i)            SYSTEMS THINKING: Identifying the problem and its root  causes

(ii)           BLUEPRINT FOR CHANGE: Developing a vision & goals

(iii)          UTILISING SYSTEMS TOOLS: Mapping the root causes, system and actors

(iv)          STRATEGIES, COLLABORATIONS & MEASURING IMPACT: Implementing your change process

There will be time dedicated to team work throughout the course. All team members are required to actively participate in team work.

Although you will be working in teams, the majority of this assessment is based on your individual contributions. Each individual in the team will be responsible for one section of the social change process, and will be assessed according to three components:

Social Change Pitch: 2(a) Individual written report (25%)

This needs to be computer typed. It is your individual contribution to the team report. The word limit is 3000 words (with a leniency of, plus or minus, 10%). (eg. each team member will submit a 3000 word section of the report).

Your written report has 2 parts: i) a 1500 word sector analysis, and ii)

1500 words comprising your individual section of the social change pitch. Even though you will be working on the same topic as your team members, this assessment is completed and marked on an individual basis.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM1001 - Communication in Business and Economics","description":"

This course addresses foundation language principles and practices, targeting the achievement of fundamental English communication skills and literacy skills required for successful advanced learning in a university context. Tailored to the specific needs of students studying Economics and Business, the course will enable students to understand, summarise and critique complex presentations and readings, to discuss ideas with others, and to communicate challenging and complex concepts and arguments clearly in both oral and written form.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b10b3437dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195f","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Exercises and Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Marks will be associated with the regular completion of formative online exercises designed to build students’ vocabulary, basic literacy, and self-knowledge.  Students’ basic English skills will be subjected to regular summative assessment using various styles of short and long quizzes and exams, including grammar and punctuation quizzes and longer exams that include written and aural comprehension tasks.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"610b3437dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e50b3437dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1d0b3437dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961937","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written Assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"20","description":"

While numerous short reports will be written and/or presented in class by each student over the course of the semester, a few will be identified as assessable


Discussion and peer assessment after both assessed and non-assessed presentations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"610b3437dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e50b3437dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"210b3437dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96194a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Course Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Students are required to maintain a course journal in which they write a short summary of weekly readings and their reflections on these readings. The journal will be marked at the end of the course on the basis of the quality of the summaries and reflections, and the ability to express complex ideas. 


Occasional feedback on samples.

Students are expected to engage actively in the discussion of topics in the workshops. A mark will be assigned for the extent and quality of each student’s in-class engagement during the semester.


Occasional discussion with students

While numerous short oral presentations will be given by each student over the course of the semester, a few will be identified as assessable. 


Discussion and peer assessment after both assessed and non-assessed presentations.

contentlets.description: This course addresses foundation language principles and practices, targeting the achievement of fundamental English communication skills and literacy skills required for successful advanced learning in a university context. Tailored to the specific needs of students studying Economics and Business, the course will enable students to understand, summarise and critique complex presentations and readings, to discuss ideas with others, and to communicate challenging and complex concepts and arguments clearly in both oral and written form.
contentlets.title: Communication in Business and Economics

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM1040 - Entrepreneurial Ecosystems","description":"

Entrepreneurship in the 21st century is rapidly evolving. Disruptive changes in technology, manufacturing, supply chains, talent, communication, and capital markets have led to the rise of global startup ecosystems. Governments, corporates and universities are recognising the potential for the next wave of economic growth to emerge from disruptive startup enterprises, and are working together to nurture them via grants, tax incentives, direct funding, subsidised space, education, competitions, purchasing policies, mentoring and partnerships.


This course provides exposure to the fundamentals of global entrepreneurship ecosystems and the practical aspects of identifying, evaluating, and moving business ideas forward in them. The course inspires students to critically think about how entrepreneurs identify opportunities, understand customer needs, harness resources, create innovative business models, attract capital and solve real-world challenges.


The course addresses key contemporary topics in entrepreneurship ecosystems and their application in any field—from business and design to healthcare and product development. The course aims to provide foundational knowledge of entrepreneurship ecosystems, lean startup and design thinking methodologies applied in startups. Different offerings of the course will allow students to:


1. explore the rise of Sydney as one of the world’s emerging entrepreneurial cities through experiential learning, employing the latest in VR and AR technologies, or


2. undertake a study tour of an international entrepreneurial ecosystem which will include online workshops on startup best practice overseas, and a two week intensive startup ecosystem experience.


This course also provides a pathway into the UNSW Founders Program. For more information visit: https://founders.unsw.edu.au


For Business School students, this course can be counted as one of your Business School electives.

Students will submit a peer assessment on the overall team experience by reflecting on their own efforts, and extend and enrich this reflection by exchanging feedback on their peers' work in terms of:

1. Attendance at meetings

2. Level of preparedness to participate in meetings 

3. Willingness to contribute to analysis, decisions, and presentation

4. Timely delivery of contribution

5. Quality of contribution and peer review feedback

6. Attendance and participation in presentation rehearsals 

7. Cooperative orientation

8. Leadership support provided 

Criteria: 

  • Insight
  • Depth of analysis of their experience

Students will be assessed on their contribution to an active learning experience. 

Criteria: 

  • Regular contribution to discussion of fieldwork, willingness to answer questions, make suggestions and be actively involved in class exercises
  • Frequent evidence of reading and engagement with the course material, presentation of insights from your reading
  • Respectful and supportive dialogue, encouragement of others’ contributions, and discussion with other class members

Formative Feedback will be provided to students in Week 4.

contentlets.description:
Entrepreneurship in the 21st century is rapidly evolving. Disruptive changes in technology, manufacturing, supply chains, talent, communication, and capital markets have led to the rise of global startup ecosystems. Governments, corporates and universities are recognising the potential for the next wave of economic growth to emerge from disruptive startup enterprises, and are working together to nurture them via grants, tax incentives, direct funding, subsidised space, education, competitions, purchasing policies, mentoring and partnerships.

This course provides exposure to the fundamentals of global entrepreneurship ecosystems and the practical aspects of identifying, evaluating, and moving business ideas forward in them. The course inspires students to critically think about how entrepreneurs identify opportunities, understand customer needs, harness resources, create innovative business models, attract capital and solve real-world challenges.

The course addresses key contemporary topics in entrepreneurship ecosystems and their application in any field—from business and design to healthcare and product development. The course aims to provide foundational knowledge of entrepreneurship ecosystems, lean startup and design thinking methodologies applied in startups. Different offerings of the course will allow students to:

1. explore the rise of Sydney as one of the world’s emerging entrepreneurial cities through experiential learning, employing the latest in VR and AR technologies, or

2. undertake a study tour of an international entrepreneurial ecosystem which will include online workshops on startup best practice overseas, and a two week intensive startup ecosystem experience.

This course also provides a pathway into the UNSW Founders Program. For more information visit: https://founders.unsw.edu.au

For Business School students, this course can be counted as one of your Business School electives.

Business Decision Making","description":"

COMM1100 is the first course in the Bachelor of Commerce and provides students with a rigorous introduction to business decision-making. Taking the perspective of a manager, students learn about economic, corporate responsibility and legal principles to understand what organisational leaders need to consider and what actions they might take.

Fundamental economic principles inform managers to ask and answer questions about how the economy works, and how these principles influence the decisions that individuals and organisations make. Core legal principles guide managers to protect value for owners and other stakeholders, and to protect both managers and organisations from public and private legal actions arising from their decisions. Corporate sustainability principles direct managers to meet the organisation’s responsibilities to a range of stakeholders and help explain why organisations may not always make the best decisions.


Link to other courses: COMM1100 is a prerequisite for Global Business Environments (COMM1150). An understanding of business decision-making is also beneficial to learn about value creation (COMM1180), how organisational resources are managed (COMM1170), and business-related problem solving more broadly (COMM1110).

Evidence-Based Problem Solving","description":"

Effective problem solving is a core capability of a successful business professional, and UNSW Commerce students need to demonstrate problem solving initiative and confidence in their studies and professional careers. Evidence-based Problem Solving introduces students to the fundamentals of a deliberate and structured approach to problem solving, balancing analysis and judgement, to avoid the common pitfalls of problem solving in organisations. The importance and power of evidence, and familiarity with the different sources of evidence, are critical for identifying, solving and communicating a problem.


Starting from business problems that organisations are confronted with, students will develop their ethical judgement, reasoning and analysis skills, and work with both quantitative and qualitative data as a preparation for critical interpretation of data.  In addition to developing an analytical mindset and new ways of working with data, students are also introduced to the basic statistical skills required for working with small data sets. This prepares students for working with big data sets and mastering common analytics tools in COMM1190 Data, Insights and Decisions. This course is a fully problem-based learning course that starts with a multi-faceted problem.


Link to other courses: This course is a prerequisite for COMM1190 Data, Insights and Decisions. It is recommended to be taken early in first year as structured problem-solving skills and the foundations of ethical judgement are universally useful. Students might also find it helpful to access the Career Accelerator’s Case Coach online tool to complement their learning.

The online discussion question assessment is a formative assessment following the StoryWall pedagogy. It is designed to help students stay on top of their learning and receive feedback on a weekly basis, and provide opportunities for students to engage in peer learning.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"739a8726db136410be4672f5f3961955","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"779a8726db136410be4672f5f3961956","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"779a8726db136410be4672f5f3961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7f9a8726db136410be4672f5f3961955","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7f9a8726db136410be4672f5f3961956","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7f9a8726db136410be4672f5f3961957","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"132b13e2db536410be4672f5f396195d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Excel Training Program","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are required to complete the GMetrix Excel training programs at both Associate and Expert level and sit practice exams at both levels in testing mode. After completing the Excel Training Program, students have the option to complete the step to obtain the Microsoft Office Specialist (MOS) Excel Certification. This next step for Excel Certification does not form part of COMM1110 but is an optional and valuable add-on that is an appealing qualification for potential employers.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"779a8726db136410be4672f5f3961956","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"80aa8726db136410be4672f5f396199b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Connected case assessment (Case Part 2)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Case 2: The two connected case assessments will investigate one overarching Case. For Case Part 1 and 2, a separate Business Report will be produced by each individual student. Part 2 will build on feedback received on Part 1, as well as consider additional material. Case Part 2 focuses on applying the problem-solving tools from the information, statistical, and ethics toolboxes to analyse the business problem, develop a solution, and communicate the solution to the stakeholders.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"739a8726db136410be4672f5f3961955","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"779a8726db136410be4672f5f3961956","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"779a8726db136410be4672f5f3961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7f9a8726db136410be4672f5f3961955","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7f9a8726db136410be4672f5f3961957","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f39a8726db136410be4672f5f3961993","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Connected case assessment (Case Part 1)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Case Part 1: The two connected case assessments will investigate one overarching Case. For Case Part 1 and 2, a separate Business Report will be produced by each individual student. Case Part 1 focuses on applying the problem-solving tools from the information, statistical, and ethics toolboxes to scope (define, frame, and disaggregate) a business problem.

“Imagination is more important than knowledge. For while knowledge defines all we currently know and understand, imagination points to all we might yet discover and create.”(Albert Einstein). This course will introduce students to creative thinking tools, design thinking and lean canvas methodology to generate, develop and evaluate innovate ideas and concepts for complex societal or business challenges.


Across every business function, creativity is central to solving complex problems, exploring new strategies and working effectively within an organisation. We implement creativity through a divergent exploration of the drivers and motivations of diverse stakeholders, before applying a convergent project management process to implement an effective solution.


The course takes a hands-on project-based approach, focusing on the big picture challenges facing businesses in the 21st century. We explore how business can react to black swan events, working through these complex practical challenges in diverse student teams. This gives students ample opportunity to develop their creative mindset, identify and test different ideas, and learn how to present their content in an engaging and persuasive way to influence others.


Link to other courses: Students are recommended to complete COMM1120 early, ideally in the first term of their Bachelor of Commerce degree (or equivalent in a double degree). The concepts and skills learned in here are highly relevant to gain a deeper understanding of COMM1180 Value Creation and will also complement learning in COMM1110 Evidence-based Problem Solving.

contentlets.description:
“Imagination is more important than knowledge. For while knowledge defines all we currently know and understand, imagination points to all we might yet discover and create.”(Albert Einstein). This course will introduce students to creative thinking tools, design thinking and lean canvas methodology to generate, develop and evaluate innovate ideas and concepts for complex societal or business challenges.

Across every business function, creativity is central to solving complex problems, exploring new strategies and working effectively within an organisation. We implement creativity through a divergent exploration of the drivers and motivations of diverse stakeholders, before applying a convergent project management process to implement an effective solution.

The course takes a hands-on project-based approach, focusing on the big picture challenges facing businesses in the 21st century. We explore how business can react to black swan events, working through these complex practical challenges in diverse student teams. This gives students ample opportunity to develop their creative mindset, identify and test different ideas, and learn how to present their content in an engaging and persuasive way to influence others.

Link to other courses: Students are recommended to complete COMM1120 early, ideally in the first term of their Bachelor of Commerce degree (or equivalent in a double degree). The concepts and skills learned in here are highly relevant to gain a deeper understanding of COMM1180 Value Creation and will also complement learning in COMM1110 Evidence-based Problem Solving.

Financial Management","description":"

This course teaches fundamental concepts and skills related to how organisations account for and financially report their business activities, and how you can comprehend, interpret and analyse the financial information that they report. It also introduces contemporary extended reporting practices (such as integrated reporting) that provide further insight into an organisation’s financial, social, and environmental impact. By the end of the course, students will develop sufficient financial literacy to read financial reports, interpret and analyse a company’s financial position and performance, control cash and other business assets, identify links between financial reporting and capital markets, and recognise sustainability and ethical issues in financial reporting.

Link to other courses: COMM1140 prepares students for COMM1170 Organisational Resources and COMM1180 Value Creation and is a formal prerequisite.  Students who have not completed COMM1110 prior to studying Financial Management should ensure they have sufficient Excel skills.

Global Business Environments","description":"

COMM1100 explored the fundamental decisions that managers need to make to keep the organisation running successfully and did so from the perspective of a structured environment. However, businesses do not operate in isolation: an organisation and the decisions their managers make exist in broader, often complex and dynamic environments.


COMM1150 now introduces the interplay of organisations with their environmental contexts to achieve both commercial and societal value. It prompts students to investigate global business environments with economic, legal, political, socio-cultural, ethical and sustainability lenses to sense disruptions and opportunities. This includes an understanding of the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and Principles of Responsible Management Education (PRME) and UNSW’s commitment to both.


Students will become familiar with the nature and role of business in society and understand the forces that drive their strategic interactions within the global business environment. The overarching purpose of this course is to provide students with a ‘big picture’ understanding of business success.


Link to other courses: COMM1150 is the second compulsory course in the Bachelor of Commerce and builds on Business Decision Making (COMM1100). Understanding the global business environment assists with a deeper comprehension of shared value creation (COMM1180) and organisational resource management (COMM1170).

contentlets.description:
COMM1100 explored the fundamental decisions that managers need to make to keep the organisation running successfully and did so from the perspective of a structured environment. However, businesses do not operate in isolation: an organisation and the decisions their managers make exist in broader, often complex and dynamic environments.

COMM1150 now introduces the interplay of organisations with their environmental contexts to achieve both commercial and societal value. It prompts students to investigate global business environments with economic, legal, political, socio-cultural, ethical and sustainability lenses to sense disruptions and opportunities. This includes an understanding of the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and Principles of Responsible Management Education (PRME) and UNSW’s commitment to both.

Students will become familiar with the nature and role of business in society and understand the forces that drive their strategic interactions within the global business environment. The overarching purpose of this course is to provide students with a ‘big picture’ understanding of business success.

Link to other courses: COMM1150 is the second compulsory course in the Bachelor of Commerce and builds on Business Decision Making (COMM1100). Understanding the global business environment assists with a deeper comprehension of shared value creation (COMM1180) and organisational resource management (COMM1170).

Sourcing, developing, deploying and mobilising resources is fundamental to creating value and achieving sustainable competitive advantage. In COMM1170 students identify the different types of financial and non-financial resources of an organisation and learn contemporary performance measures for different resource categories, before focusing on three key resources to maximise value for major stakeholders: people, technology and capital.

Link to other courses: COMM1170 is closely linked and prepares students for Creating value (COMM1180), as organisational resources are at the heart of an organisation’s ability to realise value. The fundamentals of project management taught in Collaboration and Innovation in Business (COMM1120) are also highly application to resource management.

The ultimate purpose of an organisation is to create value, whether it is financial or non-financial.  COMM1180 introduces students to the fundamentals of how an organisation identifies and taps into sources of value to meet organisational objectives. Starting from an understanding of what value is from different perspectives, students learn basic tools to understand when value is (and is not) created and to measure value. This course focuses on value created from digital strategy, customers and capital for all stakeholders. By taking an active problem-based learning approach, students will be able to appreciate the difference between business value (in a financial sense), sustainable value and social responsibilities.


Links to other courses: Collaboration and Innovation in Business (COMM1120) introduced students to business models. A business model outlines how an organisation creates and assigns value. Managing Resources (COMM1170) picks up on the operational dimension of creating value related to choices about resources.

contentlets.description:
The ultimate purpose of an organisation is to create value, whether it is financial or non-financial.  COMM1180 introduces students to the fundamentals of how an organisation identifies and taps into sources of value to meet organisational objectives. Starting from an understanding of what value is from different perspectives, students learn basic tools to understand when value is (and is not) created and to measure value. This course focuses on value created from digital strategy, customers and capital for all stakeholders. By taking an active problem-based learning approach, students will be able to appreciate the difference between business value (in a financial sense), sustainable value and social responsibilities.

Links to other courses: Collaboration and Innovation in Business (COMM1120) introduced students to business models. A business model outlines how an organisation creates and assigns value. Managing Resources (COMM1170) picks up on the operational dimension of creating value related to choices about resources.

COMM1190 teaches students the fundamental analytical and statistical tools an organisation uses to gain insights about customers, markets, competitors and itself. In this course students apply statistics and data analysis skills to real large data sets with a focus on applications, rather than methods. They will learn how to describe, collect/source and analyse business data from a variety of business domains such as finance, marketing, management, risk analysis, etc. Effectively communicating data insights and recommendations to a non-technical audience, including data visualisation and simple dashboards, rounds off this highly applied and hands-on course.


Link to other courses: COMM1190 immediately builds on Evidence-based Problem Solving (COMM1110), which introduced the basic statistical tools suitable for small data. Students will also find the analytical skills from COMM1190 useful to deepen their learning from Creating Value (COMM1180) and Organisational Resources (COMM1170).

contentlets.description:
COMM1190 teaches students the fundamental analytical and statistical tools an organisation uses to gain insights about customers, markets, competitors and itself. In this course students apply statistics and data analysis skills to real large data sets with a focus on applications, rather than methods. They will learn how to describe, collect/source and analyse business data from a variety of business domains such as finance, marketing, management, risk analysis, etc. Effectively communicating data insights and recommendations to a non-technical audience, including data visualisation and simple dashboards, rounds off this highly applied and hands-on course.

Link to other courses: COMM1190 immediately builds on Evidence-based Problem Solving (COMM1110), which introduced the basic statistical tools suitable for small data. Students will also find the analytical skills from COMM1190 useful to deepen their learning from Creating Value (COMM1180) and Organisational Resources (COMM1170).
contentlets.title: Data, Insights and Decisions

This is a foundational (Level 1) Business Analytics course that will introduce students to basic concepts, techniques, and technologies relevant for creating and managing business databases. Students will learn the basics of the Structured Query Language (SQL) language and how to use it to access data stored in relational database system, including fetch, delete, insert, and modify data. In addition, students will also learn fundamental programming concepts including data structures, networked application program interfaces, using the Python programming language.

This course is specifically for students completing a double degree in Actuarial Studies/Commerce or Commerce/Economics.  It complements ECON1101 and ECON1102 and introduces the key decisions that organisations and organistional actors need to make in response to the complex business environments in which they operate.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"0 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM1999 - myBCom First Year Portfolio","description":"

In this course, students reflect on their own past experiences accumulated through the coursework and co-curricular activities in the Bachelor of Commerce Integrated First Year. The myBCom First Year Portfolio has been designed for students to develop and demonstrate the acquisition of the first year standard of the BCom Program Learning Outcomes through a range of evidence.  Through review and reflection on learning artefacts collected throughout the Integrated First Year, students will identify evidence that demonstrates the minimum standards to curate an experiential and integrative portfolio. The curated portfolio demonstrates learning across the BCom through the BCom Program Learning Outcomes (PLO). Evidence of these outcomes include applied knowledge, problem solving, communication, teamwork, responsible business practice, global and cultural competence and leadership and align to the UNSWGraduate Attributes. The myBCom First Year Portfolio learning design promotes the knowledge, understanding, and skills that promote success across the BCom via a skills dashboard and curated learning portfolio that serves as supplementary documentation for potential employers or further academic study.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"89c961bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961999","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"One Minute Me","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Brief personal video – this digital clip is designed early in the program for students to make an artefact that displays their identity as a learner interested in business knowledge,  leadership and communication. The 1 minute me video is designed to be revised in the graduate portfolio to look back on the developing identity from leaner to professional. The script is based on: who they are, why they entered the course, and what they hope to achieve. Submitted in mid term, with updated versions at various stages and published in Evidence Showcase and Repository.

Suggested Feedback:

Self-, Peer-, Academic-, and careers advisor formative review.

ePortfolio assessment: The first year curated portfolio reflects evidence of the development plan goals including self-reflection of professional learning goals developed for the program, self-review of PLOs. 

Suggested Feedback:

Ongoing self, peer and Academic formative review, careers advisors feedback.

Formative feedback on dashboard through analytics and digital visualisations.

Data Use and Misuse","description":"

Big Data and Artificial Intelligence have changed business forever.  Business leaders and managers – not just technical specialists – need to understand the opportunities and risks for business in collecting, analysing, sharing and using data, including what is legally permissible and what is ethically appropriate.  Getting this wrong can harm individuals and societies and cause significant financial and reputational damage to the businesses involved.  This course equips students to identify and engage thoughtfully with the fundamental questions of data governance – what may we do, and what should we do, with data analytics? 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f81f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Group project on a contemporary example of data governance failure","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will be formed into small (about four students) groups to address the comparative actions of four businesses in response to a specific situation. The group report will analyse the comparative responses. The object of the project is for each student to contribute to the thinking of the group and for there to be a synthesis of the group's examination of the issues.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b81f3d1cdba43c10fe4b322af49619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f01f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f81f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f81f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"011f3d1cdba43c10fe4b322af49619ff","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Seminar participation and other classroom/online activities","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

For each of nine weeks, students will work to address business problems. There will also be work on case studies to assist in comprehension of the issues raised in the week's readings. At times these will be small groups but mainly this will be as the whole class. Students will be asked to recommend a mark and to support that recommendation with a 100-word structured advocacy piece to be submitted in Week 10 (6 pm on Friday of Week 10 on Turnitin). There will be no marks for missed sessions. That is, the mark awarded will be scaled by the proportion of sessions attended.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b81f3d1cdba43c10fe4b322af49619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f01f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f01f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f81f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"381f3d1cdba43c10fe4b322af49619f3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final research assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will undertake a research essay as part of their assessment. Students will be required to undertake research in areas related to the course and to analyse a problem designed to assess students understanding of key issues raised in the course. A marking rubric for the research essays will be posted on Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b81f3d1cdba43c10fe4b322af49619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f01f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f81f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"851f3d1cdba43c10fe4b322af49619fa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Seminar presentations","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Oral presentation: 60% of available marks, 15% of total marks. Students are expected to present on the case studies provided on Moodle in groups and all members must make an equal contribution to the oral part of the seminar. A marking rubric for the seminar presentation will be posted on Moodle. The presentation (or a link to it) must be emailed to the Lecturer in Charge by 6 pm on the day of the presentation and a (maximum) two-page summary of the key points must be attached to that email. The sumaries will be posted on Moodle. In respect of the presentation, 60% of the available marks are for the presentation as a whole, 30% are for the presenters individually and 10% for the two-page summary of the key points.

\n

Forum contribution: 40% of available marks, 10% of total marks. For each of seven weeks there will be a question related to the presented cases for online discussion by the whole class. Each student is expected to contribute to that discussion. The discussion for each week will be on a forum on Moodle. A rubric for contributions will be provided on Moodle. A mark will be provided for each contibution.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b81f3d1cdba43c10fe4b322af49619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f01f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f01f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f81f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f81f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f81f791cdba43c10fe4b322af49619c7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a3d20e14dbe43c10fe4b322af49619aa","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/COMM2050.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: commerce,business ethics and the law,legislation,common law,prme
contentlets.description: Big Data and Artificial Intelligence have changed business forever.  Business leaders and managers – not just technical specialists – need to understand the opportunities and risks for business in collecting, analysing, sharing and using data, including what is legally permissible and what is ethically appropriate.  Getting this wrong can harm individuals and societies and cause significant financial and reputational damage to the businesses involved.  This course equips students to identify and engage thoughtfully with the fundamental questions of data governance – what may we do, and what should we do, with data analytics?
contentlets.title: Data Use and Misuse

Industry Experience Program","description":"

This course provides an opportunity for Business School students to apply their academic knowledge and other professional skills in a real working environment.


Students are required to spend a minimum of 140 hours working with a partner company on a placement or project basis. The course involves preparatory modules prior to commencement, and completion of academic assignments throughout.


Enrolment in the course is restricted and only Business School students studying a single or dual degree who meet the requirements of the selection process will be admitted. Eligibility is listed on Career Accelerator webpage:


https://www.unsw.edu.au/business/student-life/career-accelerator/undergraduate/undergraduate-internships/industry-experience-program-comm2222


 


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a0728345dbf3ec10fe4b322af49619c7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

2500 words - 

Every project and report can (and should) be unique to the company.? 

The student will need to utilise information provided by the business and from external sources to develop and deliver a?professional report structured to communicate key findings on their project/experience to company representatives.?  

A two page (approx.) executive summary of outcomes (i.e. client report) should be submitted in support of the project.  ? 

In business, the information provided in reports needs to be easy to find and written in a way the client can understand. Ensure your report is divided into sections clearly labelled with headings and sub-headings. Suggested headings include: 

• Company description 

• Project outline, including concept and background - why was it undertaken? What did you hope to achieve?? 

• Project goals 

• Risk Analysis 

• Actions taken 

• Outcomes 

• Recommendations

Supervisor/Mentor will complete a report covering the students time with the company. The report will address:

  • Professionalism
  • Communication
  • Motivation and attitude
  • Independence

The mentor will discuss the report with the student, providing feedback for growth and development. The student will be able to access the report should this not be done in person. This must be completed successfully.?

Industry Consulting Project","description":"

This course provides an opportunity for Business School students to apply their academic knowledge and other professional skills to solve real world problems as part of consulting team. Partnering with Industry, students will work with a company mentor and have the opportunity to pitch their solution to a panel of industry experts.


Enrolment in the course is restricted and only Business School students studying a single or dual degree who meet the requirements of the selection process will be admitted. Eligibility is listed on Career Accelerator webpage:


https://www.unsw.edu.au/business/student-life/career-accelerator/undergraduate/undergraduate-internships/industry-consulting-project-comm2233

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM2244 - Adaptive Futures","description":"

How do I navigate my career in an ever-changing workplace?


Adaptive Futures is a project based online practicum aimed at developing and applying students’ skills, capabilities and knowledge of future workplaces.


You will learn and practice the human skills required to be successful as an individual - curiosity, creativity, empathy, and courage. You will examine how these factors underpin future career success in a rapidly changing global landscape, taking into account emerging technologies, artificial intelligence and other globalisation factors.


Guided by your lecturer and as part of a small team, you will apply these skills and capabilities to a real-life business challenge for an industry partner. Your client will present a problem related to their future workforce and, in project teams, students will investigate this challenge, workshop solutions, and provide a recommended way forward.


This course is delivered fully online and consists of pre-workshop modules, online discussion boards and three industry partner meetings.


Each experience will be different depending on the organisations we partner with.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5f50ae8fdb703410fe4b322af496190d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Team Project ","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Outline Solution Presentation - 10%

Students will present an initial outline or summary of their problem analysis/thinking to the industry partner

Final Online Recommendations/Solution Presentation - 15%

Online presentation to client and colleagues to present their final recommendations/solution to the client's Future of Work problem

Final Presentation Q&A with Client - 5%

Student will take part in Q&A with industry partner immediately after the final presentation 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5350ae8fdb703410fe4b322af4961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5b50ae8fdb703410fe4b322af496190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5f50ae8fdb703410fe4b322af496190e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1b50ae8fdb703410fe4b322af4961923","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Business Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will complete an individual report summarising their understanding of the 'Future of Work' problem, their interpretation of the problem and development of innovative solution. The report will be developed as an individual proposal that will feed into the overall solution.

As part of this report, students will identify the economic, social and environmental challenges related the client's 'future of work' problem as well as present a clear way forward.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5b50ae8fdb703410fe4b322af496190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5f50ae8fdb703410fe4b322af496190e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2f50ae8fdb703410fe4b322af496192b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Peer assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Students undertake peer assessment in conjunction with formal self-assessment. They reflect on their own efforts, and extend and enrich this reflection by exchanging feedback on their own and their peers' work

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5b50ae8fdb703410fe4b322af496190f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5b50ae8fdb703410fe4b322af4961912","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflection Journal ","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will complete a guided reflection process weekly including: 

  • Self-skill or strengths assessment to determine student's current capabilities & competencies (Formative)
  • Weekly reflective journals addressing professional development and consideration of future needs for self and industry 
  • Meta-reflection

Students will have a choice of a variety of digital mediums and tools to complete this. Reflections are submitted each week (except week 6), of which four will be marked (students will not be told which ones are marked - each worth 10%).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5b50ae8fdb703410fe4b322af496190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5b50ae8fdb703410fe4b322af4961910","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e350ae8fdb703410fe4b322af4961928","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/COMM2244.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"COMM2501","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM2501 - Data Visualisation and Communication","description":"

Data visualisation and communication is increasingly important in the field of analytics. The ability to present visual access to the huge amounts of data that business creates is an essential skill for any analyst. The creation of easily digestible visuals and graphics is often the simplest and most powerful tool to enable communication of business insights gained from data. This course introduces statistical and visualisation tools for the exploratory analysis of data. Students will learn what makes effective data visualisation and how to create interactive data visualisations using R, Tableau and other tools, including cutting-edge graphical immersive techniques. There is a strong focus on developing the skill of data storytelling: where students will learn to combine data, its visualisation and a narrative to create a powerful story to drive change.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM3020 - Global Business Practicum","description":"

COMM3020 is an experiential and intensive for-credit course. It provides students the unique opportunity to gain international understanding, exposure and workplace skills through studying and working in a specified location overseas.   


The central component of the course is the opportunity to work in a small cross-disciplinary student consulting team on a genuine business issue of a client organisation, such as local branches of international financial, marketing and technology corporations. In addition, students will also attend master classes by local industry leaders, government officials and academic experts, and learn about the local culture through field trips to important cultural landmarks and sights.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e8de6985db7fac10fe4b322af49619c2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Practicum Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Every project is unique to the company. The report must be professional, business appropriate and
useful to the host organisation given the time period in which the team have had to work on it. The
deliverables are to be agreed with the Lecturer in Charge and the company prior to the work being
done. This means that the project work, presentation and the report may not be in an academic or
written format if the client requires something different. This is difficult to document but certainly
something that is made clear throughout the workshops.

If not otherwise specified, the report should be presented in an academic format.

The student will need to utilise information provided by the business and from external sources to
develop and deliver a professional report structured to communicate key findings on their project/experience to company representatives.

In business, the information provided in reports needs to be easy to find and written in a way the
client can understand. The report should be divided into sections clearly labelled with headings and
sub-headings. Suggested headings include:
• Company description
• Project outline, including concept and background - why was it undertaken? What did you
hope to achieve?
• Project goals
• Risk Analysis
• Actions taken
• Outcomes
• Recommendations

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"68de6985db7fac10fe4b322af49619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e4de6985db7fac10fe4b322af49619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ecde6985db7fac10fe4b322af49619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"20de6985db7fac10fe4b322af49619f5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal Videos and Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

 4 x 2-3 minute video  and 1,000 word essay

These submissions provide an opportunity for you to reflect on your experience throughout the
practicum.

Reflection 1:
Instructions to students: Introduce yourself, outline your goals, expectations (what will it be like),
what you hope to achieve, fears or concerns.


Reflection 2, 3:
Instructions to students: Weekly updates on achievements progress and obstacles overcome.
How you are working in the team. How are you doing?


Reflection 4:
Instructions to students: reflect on your final presentation and your overall experience… What
have you learnt? How did it go. What would you do differently next time?


Reflection Essay:
Instructions to students: When you have completed the practicum. Revisit all your videos, especially
the first, and comment on your progress and development journey from departure, during the
practicum, to the end. This should form the basis of the reflection essay.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e4de6985db7fac10fe4b322af49619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ecde6985db7fac10fe4b322af49619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"68de6985db7fac10fe4b322af49619f9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Peer Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Review criteria of team members: Participates collaboratively and contributes effectively to
achieve team outcomes in the collaborative team process.


For example:
• facilitates team planning, goal setting, task co-ordination and progress (may show leadership in
organizing team’s work and in monitoring team’s progress and discussing issues).
• offers feedback and helps others (possibly coaching some members); is highly motivated and
supportive of others; boosts team morale and harmony.
• listens actively and communicates respectfully with all members.
• prevents or works through conflict effectively.
• attends meetings punctually and is well-prepared.
• contributes constructively to meetings; shares ideas; builds on others’ ideas; generates useful new
ideas.
• consistently meets deadlines; plans own work well.
• produces at least required share and a high quality of work that contributes significantly to team’s
achievement.
• demonstrates a high level of knowledge/skills for the task.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e4de6985db7fac10fe4b322af49619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ecde6985db7fac10fe4b322af49619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"70de6985db7fac10fe4b322af49619fd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Team Presentation and Client Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Every project is unique to the company. The project and presentation must be professional,
business appropriate and useful to the host organisation given the time period in which the team
have had to work on it. The deliverables are to be agreed with the Lecturer in Charge and the
company prior to the work being done. This means that the project work, presentation and the report
may not be in an academic or written format if the client requires something different. This is difficult
to document but certainly something that is made clear throughout the workshops.

The student will need to utilise information provided by the business and from external
sources to develop and deliver a professional presentation structured to communicate key
findings on their project/experience to company representatives. It should be presented in a
way that outlines the project undertaken and its goals, the challenges faced and the solutions
recommended by the team. The executive summary should support the presentation and
outline the presentation in a clear and concise way. The presentation and the report should
organise the information so that it is easy to find and expressed and written in a way the
client can understand. Ideally the client will discuss the presentation and report with the student,
providing feedback for growth and development.

The central component of the course is the opportunity to work in a small cross-disciplinary student consulting team on a genuine business issue of a client organisation, such as local branches of international financial, marketing and technology corporations. In addition, students will also attend master classes by local industry leaders, government officials and academic experts, and learn about the local culture through field trips to important cultural landmarks and sights.

Please visit WIL website for more information."},{"name":"General Education","code":"general_education","description":"This course is available as general education and normally taken outside the study area in which the student’s program is based. Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM3030 - Social Entrepreneurship Practicum","description":"

COMM3030 Social Entrepreneurship Practicum is a Work Integrated Learning (WIL) course designed to integrate theory with experiential practice and involve authentic and purposeful engagement with partner organisations. It enables undergraduate students to develop professional skills while working in a team on a real social entrepreneurship project.


Students work with partners from industry, social enterprises, not-for-profits and foundations to develop and conduct a variety of applied projects in different areas of social entrepreneurship. In doing so, they have the opportunity to develop their professional skills, including critical thinking, communication, teamwork,  research, innovation and creativity, entrepreneurship, leadership and many others 


In each teaching session, projects may be offered from the following fields: 


  • Social entrepreneurship and social innovation;
  • Philanthropy;
  • Impact investing;
  • Business and human rights;
  • Corporate social responsibility;
  • Pro bono and volunteering;
  • Measuring social impact;
  • Collective impact;
  • Social finance; and
  • Other related fields.

  • Identify, analyse and apply social entrepreneurship knowledge and skills to address the social challenge

  • Partner with an organisation to address a social challenge to develop professional capabilities

contentlets.description:
COMM3030 Social Entrepreneurship Practicum is a Work Integrated Learning (WIL) course designed to integrate theory with experiential practice and involve authentic and purposeful engagement with partner organisations. It enables undergraduate students to develop professional skills while working in a team on a real social entrepreneurship project.

Students work with partners from industry, social enterprises, not-for-profits and foundations to develop and conduct a variety of applied projects in different areas of social entrepreneurship. In doing so, they have the opportunity to develop their professional skills, including critical thinking, communication, teamwork,  research, innovation and creativity, entrepreneurship, leadership and many others 

In each teaching session, projects may be offered from the following fields: 

  • Social entrepreneurship and social innovation;
  • Philanthropy;
  • Impact investing;
  • Business and human rights;
  • Corporate social responsibility;
  • Pro bono and volunteering;
  • Measuring social impact;
  • Collective impact;
  • Social finance; and
  • Other related fields.
contentlets.title: Social Entrepreneurship Practicum

contentlets.description:
This experience will allow you to apply the knowledge and skills gained over the duration of your program in addressing a complex contemporary business challenge.

You will have the opportunity to demonstrate your versatile communication skills, adaptability, self-management, and logical decision-making abilities in how you approach this challenge and apply your critical thinking and problem-solving expertise to your recommendations.

Industry Experience Placement 1","description":"

The main aims of this course is to provide students with practical experience that complements their academic studies, and to give Sponsors enthusiastic and talented young achievers who may wish to work with them upon graduation.  Industry Experience Placement 1 is intended to be an introduction to the Sponsor's business, and the structures and policies in place to support the core business activities. Ideally, the Scholars should interact with several areas of the organisation.


Note: NOT available to UNSW Business School Co-op Scholars. Students will be enrolled across two terms for a total of 12UOC and must apply for this course through the Coop office here.

contentlets.description:
The main aims of this course is to provide students with practical experience that complements their academic studies, and to give Sponsors enthusiastic and talented young achievers who may wish to work with them upon graduation.  Industry Experience Placement 1 is intended to be an introduction to the Sponsor's business, and the structures and policies in place to support the core business activities. Ideally, the Scholars should interact with several areas of the organisation.

Note: NOT available to UNSW Business School Co-op Scholars. Students will be enrolled across two terms for a total of 12UOC and must apply for this course through the Coop office here.

Please visit WIL website for more information."},{"name":"Multi-Term Course","code":"multi-term_course","description":"This course is taught across multiple terms or is a member of a group of courses taken across multiple terms. In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM3202 - Industry Experience Placement 2","description":"

The main aims of this course are to provide students with practical experience that complements their academic studies, and to give Sponsors enthusiastic and talented young achievers who may wish to work with them upon graduation. This is second of two fully-assessable industry placements courses. It builds on skills and experience gained in COMM3101.


The broad objectives are:


  • Provide scholars with knowledge and practical experience within the business environment that cannot be provided at university.
  • Instil an appreciation of business processes and management while at the same time learning about company cultures and work ethics.
  • Help develop the scholars’ professional skills. Specifically, scholars should develop their intellectual, technical, personal, interpersonal, communication, and business management skills while on placement.
  • Apply theory and skills learnt across the scholars degree in a real-world environment.
  • Through progressive self-reflection scholars should become more confident in their strenghts and increase their self-perception.
  • Provide sponsors with a stream of highly talented, motivated young professionals who are dynamic and add value to the company.

Note: NOT available to UNSW Business School Co-op Scholars. Students will be enrolled across two terms for a total of 12UOC and must apply for this course through the Coop office here.

Skills Plan & Goal Setting 

Students need to draw on insights from COMM3101 to develop their Professional Development Agreement for what they hope to achieve whilst in Industry.  Goals need to be discussed with the student's supervisor/manager, as this will form part of the Sponsor Evaluation.

Sponsor Evaluation  

The student's supervisor/manager will complete a report covering the student's time within the workplace. The report will address:?? 

  • Professionalism?? 

  • Communication?? 

  • Motivation and attitude?? 

  • Independence?? 

  • Successful completion of minimum hours??

Students are required to keep a progressive journal (written or video) reflecting on how they are applying their academic learning from across their degree, and experiences in COMM3101, within the new internship. Students should cast a critical eye, identifying strengths, challenges, gaps and successful application of new skills.

Oral presentation to the student's supervisor/manager and other key members of their team(s), as available, plus university representative(s) at the end of an Internship period. While every presentation and research report can (and should) be unique to the intern and his/her experience at the company,  the presentation should cover both the student’s experience during the placement and the research report. The actual research topic should be negotiated with the company, and agreed between student, company and LiC.  

A two page (approx.) executive summary of outcomes (i.e. client report) should be submitted to the company on the day of the presentation.??

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM3303 - Industry-Research Integrated Learning","description":"

Industry-Research Integrated Learning empowers students to critically analyse and provide solutions for a small-scale business challenge, whilst being mentored by both academic and industry supervisors. Students will better understand the research process and be able to gauge their learning and development as a researcher, through completing a journal and sharing their findings using written and oral channels. Their regular industry and academic supervisor meetings will provide formative and summative feedback throughout the term to assist the students with building their self-leadership capacity.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bc13480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research Goals and Deliverables","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

After meeting with both their academic mentor and industry mentor in Week 1, students are required to submit the research goals and deliverables. These goals and deliverables will outline how the student will use critical thinking and problem solving to construct new ideas, plan and execute their research. It is envisaged that it will take approximately 100-120 hours across the term to complete this research.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7413480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7413480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7813480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0d13480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619c9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Industry/Academic Evaluation","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"20","description":"

Industry sponsor will provide detailed feedback on the suitability of the research project report and presentation to meet the research goals and deliverables. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7813480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7413480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research Project Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will make an effective and professional oral presentation of their research project to the company that has initiated the research, as well as to their academic mentor/supervisor and LIC. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7413480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7c13480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b813480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619c1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research Project Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will demonstrate their ability to write an effective and professional research project report based on an allocated ‘real world’ problem initiated from the partnering company in the business industry. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7413480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7413480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7c13480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c113480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619c5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research Progress Journal ","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

The journal will document the student's experiences, progress and reflections of their RIL course. Documentation includes fortnightly reports and evidence of research undertaken. It should also include a critical reflection on the student's process, progress, and what constitutes a successful research project in this field. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7413480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7413480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7813480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fc13480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619bc","links":[]}]},{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bc13480adb09fc10fe4b322af49619b3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research Goals and Deliverables","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

After meeting with both their academic mentor and industry mentor in Week 1, students are required to submit the research goals and deliverables. These goals and deliverables will outline how the student will use critical thinking and problem solving to construct new ideas, plan and execute their research. It is envisaged that it will take approximately 100-120 hours across the term to complete this research.

contentlets.description: Industry-Research Integrated Learning empowers students to critically analyse and provide solutions for a small-scale business challenge, whilst being mentored by both academic and industry supervisors. Students will better understand the research process and be able to gauge their learning and development as a researcher, through completing a journal and sharing their findings using written and oral channels. Their regular industry and academic supervisor meetings will provide formative and summative feedback throughout the term to assist the students with building their self-leadership capacity.
contentlets.title: Industry-Research Integrated Learning
