Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM3500 - Analytics Industry Project","description":"

This course will form one of the Capstone options for the Business Analytics major. This course gives students the opportunity to contextualise and practice their prior learnings in analytics, working on real-life business analytics problems with industry partners. Students will be working on a real business project, with the guidance of academic staff and industry mentors, and deliver actionable insights to the business problem owner. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1465517bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96198a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Professional Report & Project Charter","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

 Project Charter  (10%)

Students will be required to develop the expectations, scope, plan, modes of working, and importantly – tone for the engagement. This includes identifying the individual plans the students will work on and present as part of their team.

Professional Report  (20%)

Evaluate the concepts using insights from research and analysis to assess the fit between solution, problem, client and client market including segments, users, and other relevant research and analysis to support your thinking. 

  • Demonstrates initiative and self-direction
  • Applies discipline knowledge and skills to support the organisation’s  business functions
  • Conducts oneself in a professional manner in line with organizational expectations
  • Communicates effectively in diverse workplace situations
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1465517bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5065517bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9c65517bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0465517bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96195c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation & Digital report","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Pitch your solution to a panel (peers, academic, industry) ensuring you have a prepared slide deck. Digital report to summarize presentation in a creative and engaging fashion.

  • Demonstrates initiative and self-direction
  • Applies discipline knowledge and skills to support the organisation’s  business functions
  • Professionalism: Conducts oneself in a professional manner in line with organizational expectations
  • Communication: Communicates effectively in diverse workplace situations

Criteria: clarity of presentation; professionalism; appropriateness, relevance and creativity of content / solutions; cohesiveness; ability to answer questions

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1465517bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1865517bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5065517bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9c65517bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d865517bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4c65517bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961960","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Reflective journal entries throughout experience, and final meta-reflection, which details key milestones and tracks professional development in line with goals set, covering aspects such as  challenges, usefulness of their business knowledge in this context, cultural understanding, team experience.

Criteria:  Insight, Depth of analysis of their experience, ability to self-reflect

Business School","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"COMM3501 - Quantitative Business Analytics","description":"

Quantitative business analytics empower business decision makers to analyse complex business problems, and make better and faster decisions. It is an essential skill for an analyst in all business disciplines to use modern analytical tools and quantitative techniques. This course aims to provide students with quantitative techniques used in business analytics, with a particular focus on practical applications of modelling skills and analytical tools (e.g. using R). The course focuses on how to select appropriate predictive modelling techniques for a stated situation and how to evaluate the suitability of a model, taking into account business context and objectives. The course covers topics including regression techniques and classification methods, model selection and validation methods, linear and non-linear models, decision trees, supervised and unsupervised learning techniques, and ethical, social and regulatory issues associated with quantitative analytics. A particular focus will be placed on communication of technical results to a wide range of business decision making audiences.

This course will allow you to apply the knowledge and skills gained over the duration of your program in addressing a complex contemporary business challenge.


You will have the opportunity to demonstrate your versatile communication skills, adaptability, self-management, and logical decision-making abilities in how you approach this challenge and apply your critical thinking and problem-solving expertise to your recommendations.  



","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0ee9e5bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96199a","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Digital Learning Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students must articulate the ways they used their disciplinary training to address the challenge, and the professional skills they developed throughout the course, and how they will use the learnings from this experience in the future.

2.a Reflection-in-action videos  10%

4 x 3 minute videos

Submission of weekly journal entries using the SEAL (http://www.clips.edu.au/wp-content/uploads/SEAL-method.pdf ) method of self-reflection. Consider the discipline knowledge and capabilities learnt throughout the degree and their application in the professional context. Discuss skills gaps, any actions taken to address these, and future recommendations.

2.b Reflection-on-action paper  20%

1000 words

Use Gibbs’ Reflective Cycle to examine the experience you have just completed. (https://www.ed.ac.uk/reflection/reflectors-toolkit/reflecting-on-experience/gibbs-reflective-cycle)               

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"02e9e5bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"86e9e5bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"79e9e5bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961980","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation, Digital pack, and Q&A","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

10 slide x 15 minute voice annotated presentation

7 minute face to face Q & A session

 

Work collaboratively with internal and external stakeholders, to source relevant information and critically analyse your chosen contemporary business problem. Using the appropriate frameworks and tools, provide well-reasoned, evidence-based conclusions or recommendations in the form of a professional presentation and information deck.

 

Recommendations should consider:

 

·       Economic, social and environmental sustainability with an emphasis on future state

·       Impact of the global business environment

Students should be prepared to attend a seven minute Q&A session as part of this assessment.

1.1 Project Scope 10%

2 pages

Outline the specific project goals, deliverables and timelines.

 

1.2 Executive Summary 10%

2 pages

Professional report to accompany the presentation

The COMM3999 myBCom Graduation Portfolio is the final part of a degree-spanning professional development exercise (myBCom) to ensure students are well-positioned to demonstrate employability standards in contextualised skills and capabilities, complemented by work-integrated learning and engagement in specialised learning communities.


In combination with the COMM1999 myBCom First Year Portfolio, it requires students to consciously reflect on the senior years of their BCom as a platform/vehicle to develop/build professional skills for graduate success. Many UNSW Business School students bring a strong ‘results focus’ with them. This mindset is harnessed and scaffolded through the integrative portfolio developed across the program and showcased upon graduation.


The myBCom Graduation Portfolio culminates in students curating their portfolio and producing learning statements in a personally selected or university ePortfolio platform that reflects their identity as a  UNSW Business School BCom graduate.  BCom students will communicate their professional digital identity narratives through the purposeful selection of digital artefacts focused on showcasing the BCom Program Learning Outcomes (PLO). Evidence of these outcomes include applied knowledge, problem solving, communication, teamwork, responsible business practice, global and cultural competence and leadership and align to the UNSW Graduate Attributes.  Ongoing guidance and support are also essential to achieving the development intent of the portfolio assessments and scaffolded throughout. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b5c9a1bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96191e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"One minute me","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Brief personal video – who they are, why they entered the course, and what they hoped to achieve. Provided on day one, with updated versions at various stages and published in the Evidence Showcase and Repository   

Recommended feedback:

Self-, Peer-, Academic-, and careers advisor formative review. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a1c9a1bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"b9c9a1bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"edc9a1bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"59c961bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Skills Dashboard","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Tracking skills progress on mapped/tagged assessible tasks over 2nd and 3rd year (or equivalent in double degrees). Potentially combine pre-self-assessment and course-embedded assessment indicators.  Opportunities for self-reflection, sense of progress, and ‘triaging’ of development needs. 

Suggested Feedback:

Formative feedback on dashboard through analytics and digital visualisations.   

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2dc9a1bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a1c9a1bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"edc9a1bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"91c961bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Evidence Showcase and repository","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

Holistically communicating development outcomes and skills through exemplary work for employability developed across task 1 and 2.  

The task has two layers:  

    1. portfolio-based resumé (e.g., LinkedIn profile), which can be used to connect with or present to potential employers. It is expected (and encouraged) that students will use both evidence from their assessment tasks as well as evidence from their wider lives, thereby creating a rich and comprehensive portfolio of evidence and highlights a personal ‘brand’.   

    1. Curated professional graduate ePortfolio that demonstrates exemplary work for employability from coursework and beyond.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2dc9a1bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"69c9a1bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7dc9a1bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a1c9a1bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"b9c9a1bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"edc9a1bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d9c961bfdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/COMM3999.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Business School","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"COMM4002 - Quantitative Research Methods","description":"

This course will extend into the areas of advanced multivariate analysis and business models and thus assumes a sound knowledge of basic statistical analysis and techniques. Topics will cover a range of advanced quantitative techniques and modeling that are used for research in business today, including: multivariate analysis of variance, conjoint and choice analysis, factor and correspondence analysis, structural equation modeling, latent class analysis, analysis for panel data, models commonly used in quantitative business, including logit and probit models, and how they are used to test business theories. Special attention is paid to the underlying theory and assumptions of the methods and models used. Hands-on practical sessions will enable participants to implement these tools, techniques and models in the context of specific business applications.

Quantitative Methods for Business","description":"

This course provides an introduction to the basic mathematical and statistical tools needed in a business degree. There is an emphasis on problem solving by both manual and computer methods. The first half of the course focuses on algebra and graphs, financial mathematics and optimisation methods including linear programming and calculus. The second half of the course focuses on probability, descriptive and inferential statistics.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM5008 - Enterprise Skills","description":"

Enterprise Skills is offered as an elective. The course equips students with the employability skills needed to successfully enter the global workplace. They will gain a practical understanding of workplace contexts, cultures, and expectations of the workplace through a practical workplace experience and work integrated learning activities. By combining this with their current theoretical learning, students will be better positioned to become ethical and competent global business professionals.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"27a502dbdbb32850fe4b322af49619b1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Internship Agreement & Supervisor Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

The student is required to document their learning goals at the beginning of their internship, formulating part of the internship agreement with their supervisor. At the conclusion of the placement, the supervisor will be asked to provide feedback on their ability to demonstrate professionalism, accountability and ethical behaviour in a professional setting.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"23a502dbdbb32850fe4b322af49619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2ba502dbdbb32850fe4b322af49619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2fa502dbdbb32850fe4b322af49619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2ba502dbdbb32850fe4b322af49619b6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will complete 4 entries, (video recording), reflecting on their experience and relating each entry back to a particular workshop topic.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"23a502dbdbb32850fe4b322af49619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2ba502dbdbb32850fe4b322af49619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2ba502dbdbb32850fe4b322af49619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"37a502dbdbb32850fe4b322af49619bd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Executive Summary, Workshops and mid-session meetings","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are to produce an Executive Summary of the business they will be hosted by, including outining the business problem, company background, product or service, current competitors, and questions to be clarified.

Students must attend the 2 day workshops, and 2 compulsory mid-term meetings with the Lecturer.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2ba502dbdbb32850fe4b322af49619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2ba502dbdbb32850fe4b322af49619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2fa502dbdbb32850fe4b322af49619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bfa502dbdbb32850fe4b322af49619c1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Professional Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

3000 words

In business, the information provided in reports needs to be easy to find and written in a way the client can understand. Ensure the report is divided into sections clearly labelled with headings and sub-headings.

The report should be a complete and ‘stand-alone’ document that captures the totality of what the team has done over the course of the project. It should not assume prior knowledge on the part of the reader. The report must serve both the needs of the client and the needs of the Business School with respect to assessment. Notwithstanding this latter need, the report should still be tailored mainly for the benefit of the client. The format of the report will differ according to the nature of the project but should include:

• Executive summary

• Company description

• Project outline, including concept and background - why was it undertaken? What did you hope to achieve?

• Participants and stakeholders

• Project goals

• Analysis and recommendations

• Reference and appendix

 

Reference requirements: You must use a minimum of six (6)  references to support your analysis.

contentlets.description: Enterprise Skills is offered as an elective. The course equips students with the employability skills needed to successfully enter the global workplace. They will gain a practical understanding of workplace contexts, cultures, and expectations of the workplace through a practical workplace experience and work integrated learning activities. By combining this with their current theoretical learning, students will be better positioned to become ethical and competent global business professionals.
contentlets.title: Enterprise Skills

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"COMM5010","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM5010 - Strategy, Marketing and Management","description":"

This course is designed as a capstone core course in the Master of Commerce program. The course addresses perspectives from core and disciplinary courses in the MCom. It aims to provide students with broad business competencies and skills in developing strategic objectives for creating, maintaining, developing and capturing value for organisations and enhancing competitive advantage. It draws on knowledge and skills from completed courses in their study plans in addressing the Program Learning Goals of the Master of Commerce degree.


The course seeks to: a) integrate knowledge and skills in a framework for conceptualising, developing and implementing corporate and business strategy drawing on key concepts in marketing and organisational capabilities; b) synthesise knowledge from alternative perspectives and generate critical thinking and problem-solving skills in developing and implementing strategy; and c) engender critical reflection on the practice of business and management in working with people, and ethical decision-making; d) provide opportunities for considering global business career. Students will have opportunities of applying the above in case-studies and projects with course participants.

Data Analysis for Business","description":"

This course provides an introduction to basic analytical skills. It provides a solid basis from which data analysis techniques and tools can be applied to solve business problems. There is an emphasis on problem solving and business analytics by both manual and computer methods. The first 6 Lectures will focus on the use of quantitative methods and techniques. The second 6 Lectures will focus on the use of qualitative research methods and techniques.

contentlets.description: This course provides an introduction to basic analytical skills. It provides a solid basis from which data analysis techniques and tools can be applied to solve business problems. There is an emphasis on problem solving and business analytics by both manual and computer methods. The first 6 Lectures will focus on the use of quantitative methods and techniques. The second 6 Lectures will focus on the use of qualitative research methods and techniques.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM5020 - Global Business Practicum","description":"

This course is designed to enable postgraduate students to gain international understanding, exposure and workplace skills through studying and working in a specified location outside Australia.  Examples of locations include Indonesia, Vietnam, Hong Kong, China, and South Korea.


Structure:


  • Prior to departure students will undertake preparatory sessions in skill development and an introduction to the country they will be visiting.  These preparatory sessions will include topics such as professionalism; reporting and other professional writing and communication skills; expectations during the practicum; cultural understanding; and “getting to know” other team members.

  • While in the designated country, students will work in a local organisation for a minimum of the equivalent to 2 weeks full-time (70-80hrs).  Acting as consultants to the client organisation, small teams of 3-4 students will work on a business issue provided by the client organisation. Students will be supported by an academic and will attend master classes, provided by local leaders of business and government organisations, to understand the conduct of business in this local context.

  • After returning to Australia, students will attend a debrief session, and complete the major assessment.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1fef3281dbf3ec10fe4b322af4961969","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Peer Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Peer evaluation from team members of student's contribution to the project and the working of the group.

Criteria: Participation in team process (e.g., contribution to team planning, task coordination, supportive responses, motiviated, handles conflict); contribution to achieve outcomes (e.g., attends meetings, shared ideas, meets deadlines, dmonestrates necessary knowledge and skills).

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"53ef3281dbf3ec10fe4b322af496196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5bef3281dbf3ec10fe4b322af496196a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1bef3281dbf3ec10fe4b322af496196d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practicum Deliverables","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Project Charter 10% 

Students will allocate roles and responsibilities within their team, and agree upon their individual deliverables. This will be used as the basis for the peer evaluation of the Client deliverable. 

Client deliverable 30% 

Each student will be responsible for submitting an agreed section of a Deliverables report. The deliverables will be agreed with the LIC and are to be submitted as specified above after returning from the in-company placement. 

Criteria: 

  • Depth, breadth, relevance, use and application of relevant theories / knowledge 

  • Level of research, critical thinking and analysis 

  • Synthesis of information 

  • Creativity, innovativeness of solutions/conclusions - ability for these to be realistically implemented 

  • Quality of written communication – structure, flow and presentation of report 

 

The specific form of this report will be discussed at the Pre-departure training program. 

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"53ef3281dbf3ec10fe4b322af496196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5bef3281dbf3ec10fe4b322af496196a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5bef3281dbf3ec10fe4b322af496196b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"27ef3281dbf3ec10fe4b322af4961976","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Team Presentation and Client Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Team presentation (30 minutes) and provision of a short report (executive summary of outcomes) to client at the completion of the in-company placement.


Academic supervisor to assess and provide feedback on the presentation.  Additional feedback will also be provided by the client.

Criteria: clarity of presentation; professionalism; structure; relevance of content; ability to answer questions from client.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"53ef3281dbf3ec10fe4b322af496196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5bef3281dbf3ec10fe4b322af496196a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5bef3281dbf3ec10fe4b322af496196b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6bef3281dbf3ec10fe4b322af4961971","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The aim of reflective thinking is to foster deeper learning, critical review, and self-development from your practicum experience.

Students are required to complete five 2-3 minute videos throughout the practicum. 

The first reflection is a detailed list of personal goals and objectives before departure.  

Three videos are to be submitted whlist in-company, considering what they have learnt, how they are developing and meeting the goals and objectives they set, and anything surprising that has occurred that they did not expect. 

A final reflection is to be submitted upon return, considering the expereicne as a whole, and how they might describe this experience in an interview. 

 Following this, each student will write a short essay, summarising their individual reflections on this learning experience. It is to be submitted after returning from overseas.  This short essay will detail and discuss your learnings from your experience, for example: what you have come to know and understand across a range of areas and how this goes beyond your prior experiences - about working in business, working in another country, cultural understanding, and yourself.   

The reflection essay should be 1000 words. 

 

Criteria:  

  • Analysis of your own participation in your team and the team processes;   

  • Depth of insight and reflection on experiences in country. 

  • Ability to draw broader learnings about business, people and themselves from this experience. 

  • Self-evaluation of goal achievement

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM5030 - Social Entrepreneurship Practicum","description":"

This course is designed to provide students with the opportunity to apply their cumulative learning, and build practical business and leadership capabilities within a social entrepreneurship context. Social entrepreneurs use business thinking to develop operating models aimed at creating positive social outcomes to reach people in need. The course is taught through student engagement with a genuine social entrepreneurship project, supported by both online modules and face-to-face workshops.


Each practicum experience will be different depending on the particular project on which each student will work. Assessment tasks are designed to provide a consulting style framework to both create value for the social entrepreneurship project, and to enable students to demonstrate their ability to apply and synthesise social entrepreneurship concepts. Assessments include project scope setting, a project presentation, a final project report and a personal and professional development report.


The course is the capstone course for the Master of Commerce Global Sustainability and Social Enterprise specialisation. It is also an alternative capstone practicum course for other MCom and MCom (Ext) specialisations. This course may also be taken as a free elective in other Master of Commerce and Master of Commerce (Ext) specialisations and as an elective in the Master of Professional Accounting (Ext) program. Please refer to specialisation Handbook entries.  


The course is offered every term as well as in intensive mode in the Summer session. 


For enquiries please contact CSI Students at: csistudents@unsw.edu.au

Final Project Report (group mark)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Following the feedback received during their presentation, each team will submit a report based upon the project undertaken. Specifically, students will submit a copy of their group’s client report (or other project output as agreed by the client and project team), which was delivered to the client at completion of the Practicum.

The Project Scope Report is  3000 words. There is a leniency of plus or minus 10%.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ddc7e3e7dba65010eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e1c7e3e7dba65010eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e9c7e3e7dba65010eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e9c7e3e7dba65010eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e9c7e3e7dba65010eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"29c7e3e7dba65010eb6b147a3a9619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"3A. Project Presentation (group & individual marks)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Group task: 5%; Individual task: 15%

In their team, students will design a 10 minute project presentation for the social entrepreneur client, communicating the key aspects of the project (share their approach, reasoning and project status) in an effort to receive feedback for the Final Project Report.

The group presentation is worth 5% of the final mark.

The project presentation will be delivered in class in Week 8, Wednesday, 12 September, and should include all team members and provide:

• A brief statement about the project and its purpose (to provide a context for the presentation)

• A brief overview of the approach taken and why

• A summary of work progressed thus far and anticipated outcomes in regard to the project deliverables including challenges and risks

Immediately following the group presentation, each student will be asked to individually answer questions regarding content discussed in the presentation.

The individual Q&A responses is worth 15% of the final mark.

Receiving clear feedback from the social entrepreneur client, which will be invaluable for the final report (Assessment 3B) will be dependent upon the quality of the presentation and responses to Q&A.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ddc7e3e7dba65010eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e1c7e3e7dba65010eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e9c7e3e7dba65010eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e9c7e3e7dba65010eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e9c7e3e7dba65010eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"35c727e7dba65010eb6b147a3a961920","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"1. Project Scope Setting (individual mark)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

During the first workshop students will be allocated to a group and receive their respective Social Entrepreneurship Project Brief. Students will then engage with the Social Enterprise to scope and clarify project deliverables.

In order to assist you in contributing effectively to your group’s project deliverables (Assessment tasks 3A & 3B), this individual assessment task requires you to:

  • Examine your group’s project brief to ensure you understand what project deliverables are expected (seek clarification where required);
  • Reflect on the business knowledge and skills you have thus far learned (both in your MCom and this course, including theory, models, tools etc.) as well as conduct additional research related to the project deliverables, with the aim of identifying relevant knowledge and skills for your group project deliverables;
  • Write a 1,000 word report that scopes:

          - the nature and purpose of the project
          - relevant knowledge and skills, indicating how they will assist in developing your group’s project deliverables
          - an implementation outline, including timeline, required resources and any identified risks

[A table designed to capture the alignment of relevant material and project time line might be used and located at the front of your scoping document. Such a table will not be included in the 1,000 word length].

•The report must be referenced correctly and provide a Reference List (Harvard referencing style)

Project Presentation (group & individual marks)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Group task: 5%; Individual task: 15%

In their team, students will design a 10 minute project presentation for the social entrepreneur client, communicating the key aspects of the project (share their approach, reasoning and project status) in an effort to receive feedback for the Final Project Report.

The group presentation is worth 5% of the final mark.

The project presentation will be delivered in class in Week 8, Wednesday, 12 September, and should include all team members and provide:

• A brief statement about the project and its purpose (to provide a context for the presentation)

• A brief overview of the approach taken and why

• A summary of work progressed thus far and anticipated outcomes in regard to the project deliverables including challenges and risks

Immediately following the group presentation, each student will be asked to individually answer questions regarding content discussed in the presentation.

The individual Q&A responses is worth 15% of the final mark.

Receiving clear feedback from the social entrepreneur client, which will be invaluable for the final report (Assessment 3B) will be dependent upon the quality of the presentation and responses to Q&A.

During the first workshop students will be allocated to a group and receive their respective Social Entrepreneurship Project Brief. Students will then engage with the Social Enterprise to scope and clarify project deliverables.

In order to assist you in contributing effectively to your group’s project deliverables (Assessment tasks 3A & 3B), this individual assessment task requires you to:

  • Examine your group’s project brief to ensure you understand what project deliverables are expected (seek clarification where required);
  • Reflect on the business knowledge and skills you have thus far learned (both in your MCom and this course, including theory, models, tools etc.) as well as conduct additional research related to the project deliverables, with the aim of identifying relevant knowledge and skills for your group project deliverables;
  • Write a 1,000 word report that scopes:

          - the nature and purpose of the project
          - relevant knowledge and skills, indicating how they will assist in developing your group’s project deliverables
          - an implementation outline, including timeline, required resources and any identified risks

[A table designed to capture the alignment of relevant material and project time line might be used and located at the front of your scoping document. Such a table will not be included in the 1,000 word length].

•The report must be referenced correctly and provide a Reference List (Harvard referencing style)

It is intended that students’ individual scoping reports will provide a rich source of material to assist teams more quickly determine how to proceed with their group project deliverables (Assessments 3A and 3B).

contentlets.description:
This course is designed to provide students with the opportunity to apply their cumulative learning, and build practical business and leadership capabilities within a social entrepreneurship context. Social entrepreneurs use business thinking to develop operating models aimed at creating positive social outcomes to reach people in need. The course is taught through student engagement with a genuine social entrepreneurship project, supported by both online modules and face-to-face workshops.

Each practicum experience will be different depending on the particular project on which each student will work. Assessment tasks are designed to provide a consulting style framework to both create value for the social entrepreneurship project, and to enable students to demonstrate their ability to apply and synthesise social entrepreneurship concepts. Assessments include project scope setting, a project presentation, a final project report and a personal and professional development report.

The course is the capstone course for the Master of Commerce Global Sustainability and Social Enterprise specialisation. It is also an alternative capstone practicum course for other MCom and MCom (Ext) specialisations. This course may also be taken as a free elective in other Master of Commerce and Master of Commerce (Ext) specialisations and as an elective in the Master of Professional Accounting (Ext) program. Please refer to specialisation Handbook entries.  

The course is offered every term as well as in intensive mode in the Summer session. 

For enquiries please contact CSI Students at: csistudents@unsw.edu.au

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM5040 - Entrepreneurial Ecosystems","description":"

Entrepreneurship in the 21st century is rapidly evolving. Disruptive changes in technology, manufacturing, supply chains, talent, communication, and capital markets have led to the rise of global startup ecosystems. Governments, corporates and universities are recognising the potential for the next wave of economic growth to emerge from disruptive startup enterprises, and are working together to nurture them via grants, tax incentives, direct funding, subsidised space, education, competitions, purchasing policies, mentoring and partnerships.


This course provides exposure to the fundamentals of global entrepreneurship ecosystems and the practical aspects of identifying, evaluating, and moving business ideas forward in them. The course inspires students to critically think about how entrepreneurs identify opportunities, understand customer needs, harness resources, create innovative business models, attract capital and solve real-world challenges.


The course addresses key contemporary topics in entrepreneurship ecosystems and their application in any field—from business and design to healthcare and product development. The course aims to provide foundational knowledge of entrepreneurship ecosystems, lean startup and design thinking methodologies applied in startups. Students will explore the rise of Sydney as one of the world’s emerging entrepreneurial cities through experiential learning, employing the latest in VR and AR technologies.


This course provides an initial overview of entrepreneurship ecosystems that can be built on with courses from the Innovation and Entrepreneurship specialisation including MGMT5611 Entrepreneurship and New Venture Management.


This course also provides a pathway into the UNSW Founders Program. For more information visit: https://founders.unsw.edu.au

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"226285f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961934","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Ecosystem comparative analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will conduct a comparative analysis of the Sydney ecosystem with their home city (or a city of their choosing). The analysis should use the 'Eight Pillars' Framework (WEF, 2013). The analysis is to be presented in the form of a 1500 word report. 

Due date: Week 8

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5a6285f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"966285f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"026245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Students submit an 800-1000 word journals entry detailing their own reflections on this experience as it occurs covering aspects such as challenges, characteristics of entrepreneurs and development of their startup ecosystem knowledge.

Due date: Week 10

 Criteria:

  • Insight
  • Depth of analysis of their experience
  • Ability to self-reflect
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"126285f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"966285f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4a6245f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Contribution to class and field work","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be assessed on their contribution to an active learning experience. 

Criteria: 

  • Regular contribution to discussion of fieldwork, willingness to answer questions, make suggestions and be actively involved in class exercises
  • Frequent evidence of reading and engagement with the course material, presentation of insights from your reading
  • Respectful and supportive dialogue, encouragement of others’ contributions, and discussion with other class members

Formative feedback will be provided to students in Week 4.

contentlets.description:
Entrepreneurship in the 21st century is rapidly evolving. Disruptive changes in technology, manufacturing, supply chains, talent, communication, and capital markets have led to the rise of global startup ecosystems. Governments, corporates and universities are recognising the potential for the next wave of economic growth to emerge from disruptive startup enterprises, and are working together to nurture them via grants, tax incentives, direct funding, subsidised space, education, competitions, purchasing policies, mentoring and partnerships.

This course provides exposure to the fundamentals of global entrepreneurship ecosystems and the practical aspects of identifying, evaluating, and moving business ideas forward in them. The course inspires students to critically think about how entrepreneurs identify opportunities, understand customer needs, harness resources, create innovative business models, attract capital and solve real-world challenges.

The course addresses key contemporary topics in entrepreneurship ecosystems and their application in any field—from business and design to healthcare and product development. The course aims to provide foundational knowledge of entrepreneurship ecosystems, lean startup and design thinking methodologies applied in startups. Students will explore the rise of Sydney as one of the world’s emerging entrepreneurial cities through experiential learning, employing the latest in VR and AR technologies.

This course provides an initial overview of entrepreneurship ecosystems that can be built on with courses from the Innovation and Entrepreneurship specialisation including MGMT5611 Entrepreneurship and New Venture Management.

This course also provides a pathway into the UNSW Founders Program. For more information visit: https://founders.unsw.edu.au

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM5044 - Adaptive Futures","description":"

What will the future workforce look like? What skills do I need to thrive?


COMM5044 Adaptive Futures is a project based online practicum aimed at developing and applying a student’s business skills and knowledge to the future workplace.


We begin by examining the future of work. We look at the skills required to be successful as an individual, as well as the capabilities organisations need to remain successful in the rapidly changing global landscape. We focus on human factors - curiosity, creativity, empathy, and courage – capabilities that facilitate the effectiveness of the workforce, regardless of emerging technologies or other globalization factors.


We then partner with industry to apply these skills and capabilities to a real-life business challenge. An industry partner will present a problem related to their future workforce. In project teams, we investigate this challenge, workshop solutions, and provide a recommended way forward.


This course is delivered fully online and consists of pre-workshops modules, online discussion boards and three industry partner meetings.


Each practicum experience will be different depending on the organisations we partner with.


Attendance is required at all online workshops.

Presentation and Q&A  15%

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM5201 - Social Enterprise: Doing Business for Social Good","description":"

COMM5201 Social Enterprise: Doing Business for Social Good is an experiential and intensive course offered in T2C which enables PG students to gain experience in developing a social business model to address a social gap/need in a profitable way.


Students will learn about the ‘what’, ‘why’ and ‘how’ of social business and how to apply their new and existing knowledge and skills through developing a social business case for a competition. Working in small teams, students will develop and draw inspiration from the United Nation's Sustainable Development Goals to identify a social or environmental gap to address. Students will be coached throughout by experts in innovation and social enterprise.


The course is designed to guide students through a practical innovation process called the Double Diamond, beginning with discovering the problem then defining the problem, before developing the solution and finally delivering the solution, culminating in a presentation to a judging panel with deep expertise in social business, innovation, and entrepreneurialism. The winning team will receive incubation support from Founders UNSW and the Michael Crouch Innovation Centre to further develop the business model should they wish.


This course aims to:


  • Increase students' understanding of how their business knowledge may be applied in practice, in particular in a social business context.
  • Develop students' collaboration and teamwork capabilities and interpersonal skills.
  • Develop student's ability to clearly and effectively communicate with diverse groups of people.
  • Increase students' employability through the development of innovation and creativity skills.

contentlets.description:
COMM5201 Social Enterprise: Doing Business for Social Good is an experiential and intensive course offered in T2C which enables PG students to gain experience in developing a social business model to address a social gap/need in a profitable way.

Students will learn about the ‘what’, ‘why’ and ‘how’ of social business and how to apply their new and existing knowledge and skills through developing a social business case for a competition. Working in small teams, students will develop and draw inspiration from the United Nation's Sustainable Development Goals to identify a social or environmental gap to address. Students will be coached throughout by experts in innovation and social enterprise.

The course is designed to guide students through a practical innovation process called the Double Diamond, beginning with discovering the problem then defining the problem, before developing the solution and finally delivering the solution, culminating in a presentation to a judging panel with deep expertise in social business, innovation, and entrepreneurialism. The winning team will receive incubation support from Founders UNSW and the Michael Crouch Innovation Centre to further develop the business model should they wish.

This course aims to:

  • Increase students' understanding of how their business knowledge may be applied in practice, in particular in a social business context.
  • Develop students' collaboration and teamwork capabilities and interpersonal skills.
  • Develop student's ability to clearly and effectively communicate with diverse groups of people.
  • Increase students' employability through the development of innovation and creativity skills.

Social and environmental sustainability is increasingly viewed by businesses as a key to increased productivity, growth trajectory, and long term value creation. This is a result of both internal and external factors, including the drive for resource efficiency in a world of decreasing natural resources, the need to attract and retain staff, many of whom require their employer to act in a socially and environmental responsible manner, building a loyal customer base locally and abroad, and the responsibility to account for social and environmental impacts through voluntary and involuntary performance reporting. This course will examine social and environmental sustainability from a foundation of stakeholder theory, systems thinking, and case study method with the aim of equipping students with the knowledge and skills to create long-term economic value while building healthy ecosystems and strong communities.

Sustainability Champion Report (individual mark)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Student will work on both a Sustainability Champion Report (2A) and Sustainability Champion Presentation (2B). The report is an individual task and the presentation is a group task. These tasks involve your investigation of an organisation that is considered to be a ‘Sustainability Champion’, enabling you to apply the theory discussed in the course to real-world examples, and to develop your skills in project management, teamwork, organisational analysis, report writing and delivering a presentation.

Membership of project groups will be finalised by the end of the first intensive weekend session. Thereafter, groups are required to nominate a business as a sustainability champion on a first come first serve basis (no two teams can choose the same organisation).

For task 2A, each member of the group will submit an analysis of the nominated "Sustainability Champion" in the form of a written consultant-style report of no more than 3000 words in length.

Student will work on both a Sustainability Champion Report (2A) and Sustainability Champion Presentation (2B). The report is an individual task and the presentation is a group task. These tasks involve your investigation of an organisation that is considered to be a ‘Sustainability Champion’, enabling you to apply the theory discussed in the course to real-world examples, and to develop your skills in project management, teamwork, organisational analysis, report writing and delivering a presentation.

Membership of project groups will be finalised by the end of the first intensive weekend session. Thereafter, groups are required to nominate a business as a sustainability champion on a first come first serve basis (no two teams can choose the same organisation).

For task 2B, the entire group will provide an integrated analysis of the nominated "Sustainability Champion" in the form of an in-class presentation (15mins).

This component entails the assessment of the level of your informed contribution to activities (face to face and online) throughout the term. Marks will not be awarded for simply attending class. You are required to be actively involved in the course. This may involve raising questions, making insightful comments or proposing or building on ideas to solve problems. In order to participate in an informed manner, it is essential that you have completed the online modules before attending the intensive weekend classes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0411a9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4011a9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8c11a9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c011a9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c411a9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96199d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"c811a9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bb01a9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Newshound Essay (individual mark)","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This assignment requires you to consider a recent (last 6 months) business-related article from print, broadcast or online and apply the concepts you are learning to the specifics of the situation. This is an individual assessment task.

Specifically, you will need to use at least two concepts from Topics 1-4 to analyse the case described in the article. You may choose the concepts that you feel are most relevant, but you must choose two and they must be related to Topics1- 4 of Social and Environmental Sustainability (not other courses).

Your Newshound essay should provide an informed and original analysis. Specifically, the assessment criteria will be based on four components:

1. Quality of analysis and depth of reflection

2. Evidence of your thinking about the case and its relation to the conceptual material

3. Consistent, clear and well-supported argument

4. Structure, written expression, length & presentation

This assessment task will focus on an in-class exercise that involves you identifying your core values, developing, and sharing your goals to better align your actions with these values. This could involve goals about  living more sustainability and/or professional goals that relate to making a positive impact. Accompanying this exercise are two brief reflections (250-500 words each) at the mid-point and end of the course. Further details, including templates for this exercise, will be provided on Day 1 of the course. As you prepare for this course, it would be helpful to reflect on the following questions:   "What are my core values?" followed by "Why are they important to me?".

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"COMM5203","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM5203 - Social and Environmental Outcomes Measurement","description":"

Across government, business, and the not-for-profit sector there is a growing demand for organisations to measure their social and environmental outcomes and impact while social enterprises in particular rely on the ability to evaluate and communicate their social and financial impact for investment and scalability. Yet measuring outcomes and impact is not a straightforward process. What and how to measure, how to communicate outcomes and impact effectively, and how to manage the process of evaluation within an organisation are just some of the associated challenges. Beginning with an examination of ‘why measure’, this course will then turn to a practical application of ‘what and how to measure outcomes and impact’, how to communicate social and environmental measurement outcomes and impact to key stakeholders, and conclude with an assessment of how an outcomes and impact framework might facilitate organisations to deliver on their mission, support organisational learning, and provide capacity for organisational change and sustainability.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8511e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961955","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"3. Online presentation (individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment will require students to formulate a business pitch. They will be asked to identify a social or environmental issue and propose a program/organisation/business that will address this issue. Students will develop a ‘problem tree’ to describe the wider social or environmental issue, formulate a ‘theory of change’ and present the vision, mission, goals and objectives of the program/business/organisation proposed to address the issue.

Students will receive feedback and a final mark within two weeks of the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0511e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961949","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4111e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b811e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"c911e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f411e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961946","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2c11e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"4. Group Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment will require students to write a 3500-word report. Working in groups of three, students will identify a current program/organisation/business addressing a social or environmental issue of interest across the group. They will formulate a theory of change and logic model for the program/organisation/business and  develop an evaluation plan to demonstrate the social and environmental impact of their activities. In this process, students should critically discuss evaluation approaches, their applicability to the selected program/business/organisation, detail the selected approach and propose the plan for evaluation, including program outcomes, indicators to measure these outcomes and data collection strategies. Students need to communicate this evaluation plan in a business report format.

Students will receive feedback and a final mark within two weeks of submission.


","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0511e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961949","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4111e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8d11e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b811e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"c911e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f411e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961946","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2c11e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96191c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"2. Critical Essay (individual mark)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment will require students to write a 2500 word critically review of the ‘promises and pitfalls’ of measuring outcomes and impact by answering the following question: “What are the challenges that organisations (businesses or not-for-profit organisations) face when assessing their social and environmental outcomes?”. In answering the question students will be required to draw on lessons learned from the first online module, the first face-to-face intensive seminar and relevant literature that they have researched beyond the required readings.

Students will be assessed on their ability to demonstrate critical thinking skills, to formulate an argument, and to justify their argument with reference to appropriate evidence.

Students will receive feedback and a final mark within two weeks of submission.

Participation (individual mark)","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Participation marks will be assessed according to contributions made by students in the online discussion forums. Active participation and interaction with peers is a vital ingredient in learning and is assessed on the student’s contributions to discussion and other learning activities. The LIC will prepare four discussion topics throughout the online learning modules and students are expected to debate the respective topics. They should incorporate the concepts and theories from the online course materials and those discussed in the face-to-face class to express their own ideas, experience and opinions as well as respond to comments and contributions from fellow students.

contentlets.keywords: commerce,social measurement,measuring social outcomes,measuring environmenatl impact
contentlets.description: Across government, business, and the not-for-profit sector there is a growing demand for organisations to measure their social and environmental outcomes and impact while social enterprises in particular rely on the ability to evaluate and communicate their social and financial impact for investment and scalability. Yet measuring outcomes and impact is not a straightforward process. What and how to measure, how to communicate outcomes and impact effectively, and how to manage the process of evaluation within an organisation are just some of the associated challenges. Beginning with an examination of ‘why measure’, this course will then turn to a practical application of ‘what and how to measure outcomes and impact’, how to communicate social and environmental measurement outcomes and impact to key stakeholders, and conclude with an assessment of how an outcomes and impact framework might facilitate organisations to deliver on their mission, support organisational learning, and provide capacity for organisational change and sustainability.
contentlets.title: Social and Environmental Outcomes Measurement

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"COMM5204","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM5204 - Investing for Local and Global Impact","description":"

Investing with the specific aim of achieving positive social and/or environmental impact has become increasingly recognised as holding enormous potential for unlocking private capital, enabling new solutions to pressing social and environmental challenges, and helping to shape a new landscape that is blurring the traditional lines between investment and philanthropy. Investments can be made by business and corporations, governments and individual investors (small and large) while social purpose organisations are developing investment strategies to attract investors to finance the development of social innovation and to trial environmentally friendly production processes and delivery. Impact investment has been particularly popular within developing and emerging markets across the globe.  The aim of this course is to examine the history, concepts and current practices in investing for local and global impact while providing the opportunity to develop practical skills in including the development and application of social impact investment strategies from an investor, investee and policy development perspective.


COMM5204 Investing for Local and Global Impact is a general elective in the Finance specialisation and an elective in the Global Sustainability and Social Enterprise specialisation in the Master of Commerce and Master of Commerce (Extension) programs.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7511e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"4. Critical Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

Assessment 4 is a 2,000 word essay requiring a critical assessment of how the theory of social impact investment relates to practice with evidence drawn from the reports written for Assessment 1 and assessment 2 and associated learning. In particular, it will draw on comparative analysis between Australia and one other country (to be agreed with LiC) to draw learnings for policy development in each country.

Multiple choice and short answer quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Assessment 1 is a multiple choice and short answer quiz aimed to ensure students understand the core principles and concepts that underpin social impact investment covered the online Modules 1 and 2. This must be completed before the first intensive weekend of classes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3111e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3d11e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b111e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fd11e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5911e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961991","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"2. Investor client report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Assessment 2 is a 1,500-word report requiring the preparation of advice to an investor client in the social impact investment sector with both a local and global presence. The report will be based on an actual market participant, with specific deliverables set by the investor client. This will require an understanding of the emergence of social impact investment and its role in, and potential for, addressing social and environmental challenges facing local and global communities while generating a market return. Further details along with the client brief are provided on Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3111e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3d11e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7d11e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b111e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"b911e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fd11e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a111e9f7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961996","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"3. Investee client report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Assessment 3 is a 1,500-word report requiring the preparation of advice to an investee client in the social impact investment sector with both a local and global presence. This will be based on an actual social investment project with specific deliverables set by the investee client. Further details along with the client brief are provided on Moodle.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"COMM5205","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM5205 - Leading Change for Sustainability","description":"

Leading Change for Sustainability is a course designed for future leaders who are passionate about creating positive social and environmental change.


Your ideas and passion for sustainability and resilience are just the first step. You need skills in leadership, creativity, systems thinking, communication and models for cultural change so that you can influence key decision-makers, build networks and make your idea a reality. You need an awareness of change processes and an understanding of ethics and human rights to lead sustainable change, locally and globally.


How do you lead cultural change towards a sustainable future for all organisational types?


How do you pursue social and environmental goals from within a multinational company or a start up?


What are the ethical and human rights implications of cultural change?


Sustainability has become a key driver in many organisations, from large foundations to social enterprises, not-for-profits working with government to provide services, and small to large businesses. This course explores how to create and implement sustainability strategies for different organisational types. We take a broad view of sustainability based on the Sustainable Development Goals, acknowledging the human, social, economic and environmental elements of positive cultural change. The course uses in-depth case studies and examines complex aspects of sustainability leadership faced by leaders from business, government and civil society. As a result of the learning strategies drawn upon throughout the course, you will complete the course with a broad understanding of sustainability leadership and you will be able to identify the keys to initiating and sustaining positive cultural change.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a7d21de2db0fd050358b403c3a96191f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"1. Multiple choice and short answer quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will complete an online quiz of 15 multiple choice and short answer questions based on the learning materials and readings from module one of the course. Students will have one hour to complete the quiz. Students will be given feedback on their results at the conclusion of the quiz deadline, within a week after all students have completed the quiz.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e7d21de2db0fd050358b403c3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ebd21de2db0fd050358b403c3a9619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"efd21de2db0fd050358b403c3a9619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"efd21de2db0fd050358b403c3a9619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"37d25de2db0fd050358b403c3a961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"2. Leadership simulation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Task description 

(a) Individual presentation/contribution to role play 20% 

(b) Contribution to team collaboration 10% 

(c) 2000-4000 word (depending on team size) written report 20% 

During the second intensive weekend class, students will participate in a leadership simulation that will be completed in teams. Preparatory materials for the simulation will be provided on moodle in the weeks prior to the weekend class. Each person will play a different role in the simulation and will apply the leadership skills that they have been taught. This will be assessed through the individual's presentation and contribution to the role play. There will also be a mark allocated for the individual's participation in the team in which they are allocated. Following the simulation, students will submit a written report in teams outlining the sustainability strategy they adopted. In the report, students will draw on the course theory to outline their approach to sustainability and cultural change. They will also include the ethical and human rights implications of their strategy. Students will receive written feedback and a final mark on the date of the official release of UNSW course results.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e7d21de2db0fd050358b403c3a9619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e7d21de2db0fd050358b403c3a9619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e7d21de2db0fd050358b403c3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ebd21de2db0fd050358b403c3a9619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"efd21de2db0fd050358b403c3a9619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"efd21de2db0fd050358b403c3a9619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4ce25de2db0fd050358b403c3a961907","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"3. Critical reflection on leadership practice","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will complete a 2000-word critical reflection on their past, present and future leadership styles and practice. The leadership reflection asks students to identify their leadership, communication and conflict transformation styles along with their associated strengths and challenges. They will then identify tools that they can use to build these capacities and acquire others. Students are encouraged to use creative mixed media methods of presenting their leadership reflection (i.e. in the form of a video, written work, audio recording etc.). Students will receive written feedback and a final mark within two weeks of submission.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"COMM5501","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"COMM5501 - Data Visualisation and Communication","description":"

Data visualisation and communication is increasingly important as a complement to the study of analytics. The ability to present visual access to the huge amounts of data that business or government creates is an essential skill for any analyst. The creation of easily digestible visuals graphics are often the simplest and most powerful tool to enable communication of insights gained from data. 


This course will introduce statistical and visualisation tools for the exploratory analysis of data. Students will learn what makes an effective data visualisation and how to create interactive data visualisations. Visualisation in R, Tableau and other tools including cutting-edge graphical, immersive techniques will be used.There will be a strong focus on developing the skill of data storytelling: where students will learn to combine data, visualise it and develop a narrative to create a powerful story to drive change.


 


NOTE: Assumed knowledge - A level of knowledge equivalent to a first-year undergraduate basic statistics course is assumed. Students without such knowledge are advised to complete an appropriate self-assessment of university statistics knowledge before the commencement of their first term and complete a Stats bridging course where appropriate.
